deltas.text: Whenever a part of a circuit can be 'replaced' by an identical component...
It means that, viewing from the perspective of the two nodes that separate that part from the rest of the circuit...
...The replacement behaves exactly the same in terms of VOLTAGE across and CURRENT through.
For example, two resistors in series can be replaced by one resistor with the sum of their resistances. (Req = R1 + R2)
Two resistors in parallel sum their conductances. This manifests as the clunky equation Req = 1/(1/R1 + 1/R2).
In general, most components either sum in series or sum in parallel. If they sum normally in one of these, they will often sum their inverses in the other.
Capacitors, for instance, sum in parallel and use Ceq = 1/(1/C1 + 1/C2) in series.
Inductors sum in series and use Leq = 1/(1/L1 + 1/L2) in parallel.
Voltage sources sum in series and should not be placed in parallel.
Current sources sum in parallel and should not be placed in series.
Op-amps, diodes, and transistors are all nonlinear and thus cannot be easily combined. [END]
